headline: Parliament Unites in Tribute to Former Prime Minister Jim Bolger, Adjourns in Respect
summary: Parliament set aside all other business as party leaders and members from across the political spectrum rose to pay tribute to former Prime Minister Rt Hon Jim Bolger, who died on October 15. Speakers shared personal anecdotes and reflected on his complex and transformative legacy, from controversial economic reforms to his celebrated role in advancing Treaty of Waitangi settlements. Following the tributes, the House adjourned for the day as a mark of respect.

topicSummaries.topic: Cross-Party Tributes Honour the Life and Legacy of Jim Bolger
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: Remembering the leader who oversaw major economic reforms, the introduction of MMP, and the beginning of modern Treaty settlements helps explain the foundations of contemporary New Zealand politics.
topicSummaries.content: In a session dedicated entirely to his memory, parliamentarians from all parties paid tribute to former Prime Minister Jim Bolger. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon moved the motion to adjourn, remembering Bolger as a leader with an "innate sense of fairness" who guided New Zealand through sweeping economic, social, and constitutional changes. A recurring theme was the complexity of his legacy; speakers acknowledged controversial policies like the Employment Contracts Act while universally praising his courage and conviction in initiating major Treaty of Waitangi settlements with iwi like Waikato-Tainui and Ngāi Tahu. Leaders from Labour, Te Pāti Māori, and the Greens highlighted his evolution in later life, where he championed causes like fair pay agreements, and his consistent belief that the nation's success was tied to the success of Māori.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: Jim Bolger's life is full of contradictions. His Government sold the Bank of New Zealand and then he was the inaugural chair of the new Government-owned Kiwibank. His Government ushered in the Employment Contracts Act and then subsequently he chaired a working group that led to the establishment of fair pay agreements.

keyExchanges.speaker: Debbie Ngarewa-Packer (Co-Leader—Te Pāti Māori)
keyExchanges.quote: Tukoroirangi Morgan rangatira said that Jim Bolger leaves a legacy in the Treaty settlement space that will remain unsurpassed. He modernised the whole process of reconciliation in an effort to bring Aotearoa and New Zealand closer together.

conclusion: The day in Parliament was marked by a rare moment of cross-party unity, reflecting on a leader whose legacy of both divisive reform and historic reconciliation continues to shape the nation.
